title: HK Nutrition
desc: I embraced WordPress to make this fully responsive content-managed site for a great nutritionist, who can now merrily upload recipes, testimonials etc without having to get a developer (me) involved.

title: Buzz Junior
desc:
Buzz Junior is the kid's version of the popular PlayStation game Buzz.

I assembled this Flash web site and built the logic, while the crew at BLOC provided most of the animations (I accept responsibility for the spider and caterpillar though).

detailPic.desc: This caterpillar appears periodically and crawls around the edge of the browser window.
A spider sometimes dangles in front of the page, if you click him his thread breaks and he falls.

title: ALALA / All for Love and Love for All
desc: ALALA is a charity supporting children orphaned by natural disaster. I built and carry out ongoing maintenance on their website.

title: Kempson Garden Services
desc: Kempson Garden Services offer garden maintenance and design services, this is their site.

title: Truck Town
desc:
Built to accompany a series of children's books, the Trucktown site is aimed at young boys and is well noisy.

There are some really cute characters in the books (and cool animations and graphics from D.O. in the site).

title: Life Tips: 1. BISH: Open Your Eyes
desc: Born in the woods, this is your first experience.

title: Life Tips: 2. BASH: Focus on the Beauty
desc: See both positive and negative, but focus on the positive so it stands out like the blue flowers.

title: Life Tips: 3. BOSH: Perspective
desc: A pebble that is bigger than a person who is bigger than a tractor. Sometimes the little things can seem like a big deal. Othertimes we miss obvious important things.

title: Life Tips: 4. BE LUCKY!
desc: Seems like useless advice but we make our own luck...

title: Peaches, Chance
desc: The painting is of beautiful Peaches but the painting is called "Peaches, Chance" and is about motherhood. Trust me this is more than a portrait to me, I cried twice while I painted this, once at the beginning when I started her eyes and once at the end when I had to finish her eyes. One time when I looked after her she was dehydrated and wouldn't drink because she was missing her owner, I proper felt her that day x miss her xx

title: Drift
desc:
Just...drift.

I used metallic paint to suggest reflected moonlight, there's an animated GIF to illustrate here.

title: All My Rainbow People
materials: Modelling Paste, Gloss Medium, Iridescent Medium, Pigment Ink and Acrylic on Canvas
desc:
Had loads of messy fun making this. First I added crusty texture to the canvas using acrylic modelling paste. Then I took left-over pigment ink from an old broken printer, filled a few syringes up with that stuff and let it fly. After that had dried I went in with various acrylic media, highlighting certain areas and knocking back others.

Some areas of this are glossy and some are matt, and there are pearlescent areas. All this means that this painting changes dramatically with the light, looking very different in the morning compared to the evening. It does a lot of shining and shimmering.

This is dedicated to all of my beautiful, colourful, varied friends and family. You make me who I am, love you all xxxx.

title: Crawl the Copse (Eight Animals)
desc: I got into the detail and swirls in this piece. There are eight animals in the scene, you'll need to magnify to find them all.

title: Limbo: Painted or Unpainted
desc:
I wasn't sure if I should put this in the artwork or the photography section but it's something I painted so this section seemed about right.

It's the plastic sheet I cover my wall and floor with to create my work area. Over the past few years it's become covered in paint that misses the canvas. So it's a subconscious acccidental background painting. I can definitely see a watery landscape here.

title: Safe Direction
desc:
"Art is a lie that makes us realise truth, at least the truth that is given us to understand." - Pablo P

I want you to think it looks real, then I want you to be disgusted by how messy it is. Magnify it if you don't believe me.

title: Circles and Spikes
desc:
The branch growth was created using semi-autonomous techniques, letting gravity pull drips of paint down the canvas (held upside-down).

The general aim was to recreate the feeling of hectic, confusing snow that makes vision difficult. I like the repeating circles in the snowdrops, berries and sun.

title: Atoms Did Congeal and Lo! Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger was Given Form
desc: I'm a bit out of date with this one as I started painting this a long time ago and forgot about it until recently.

title: Georgie, You're Lovely When You Smile
desc: Listen to your mother.

title: Morning. Bleurgh.
desc: I made heavy use of blurring (using acrylic matt gel to help make flat but translucent colours) hoping to create a dreamy mystical feel in this painting.

title: Rushes
desc: Filthy saturation.

title: Tablet Finger Painting
desc: A new medium for me, this was painted using my fingers and a really nice app (which I recommend) called ArtFlow on an Android tablet.

title: Tarp Landscape
desc: A digitally-manipulated crop of the tarpaulin I use as a portable painting studio.

title: Hail
desc: People rise, ice falls.

title: Noble's Isle
desc: Infernal verdancy.

title: Fireaway
desc: Possibly because they let their computers tell them how to write, people sometimes get confused about where one word ends and another begins. "I maybe going for a walk", "my dog scratches me alot, but I nevermind"...such nasties as these cause me great distress. This is a trend I will not be able to reverse, so to keep the insanity-wolf from my door I have turned to exposure therapy.

title: South Downs Cows
commentPrompt: Are landscape paintings boring?
desc: Some cows. On a hill.

title: Gone Sun
commentPrompt: Are landscape paintings boring?
desc: Over the South Downs.

title: Fabric
desc:
Started in 2011, finished in 2016.

The fabric of life, human society, interconnectedness, t-shirts etc.

title: Crab Tracks, Holywell
commentPrompt: Are landscape paintings boring?
desc: The lonely path of a crab cuts through the serenery in this beach landscape.

title: M. Blue
desc:
Something I like to do with my painting is draw attention to the way our perceptual systems work.

Sometimes the viewer sees the piece from a distance or in a small thumbnail and thinks it might be a photo, then is surprised when seeing the brush strokes up-close at how messy or 'painted' it looks. A miniscule lesson in how things are not always as they seem.

title: A Beautiful Place to Meet Lucifer
desc: A sacred place with a mystical atmosphere. Some have speculated that it was once used to worship that Bringer of Light, the Morning Star, Intellectualism, Enlightenment: Lucifer.

title: Looking At Shoreham
desc:
Fairly loose rendering of this familiar view along Brighton seafront.

I'm particularly pleased with the red dot on the tower in the distance.

title: Path #1
commentPrompt: Are landscape paintings boring?
desc: This was painted on my computer using a digital pen and tablet, in an attempt to match the style I use in acrylic.

title: Foresty
commentPrompt: Are landscape paintings boring?
desc: I really tried to let go of my technique here.

title: In One Side
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc:
Everything has a death.

I wanted these paintings to feel like galactic birthing/dying places, but they are not analytical studies. Similar methods and materials were used for both paintings but this white one is less likely to fit into galactic preconceptions than its black companion.

I used processes which I had only slight control over, leaving the rest down to gravity, surface tension and capillary action. I was the instigator but the cosmos painted these.

title: Out The Other
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc:
Everything has a birth.

I wanted these paintings to feel like galactic birthing/dying places, but they are not analytical studies. I did not paint as such but just allowed the paint to fall in places which I felt added to the feeling I was trying to create. And when things went wrong, I allowed more paint to fall and cover the 'mistakes'.

I used processes which I had only slight control over, leaving the rest down to gravity, surface tension and capillary action. I was the instigator but the cosmos painted these.

title: One Thousand Dreams
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: A rendering of cosmic consciousness, the dream nebula.

title: Actualities
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: A night-flight over the sea of potentiality.

title: Drowned, Luckily
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: Kittens? Sorrows? Feelings of insecurity?

title: Neverglades
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: Semi-controlled natural lines...satellite view/map view.

title: Filamentary
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: I'm interested in patterns that recur in nature, especially when they appear in both tiny and gargantuan places. There are strong similarities in images of the universe and images of neurons. This painting is inspired by the way those things look.

title: Ride Waves / Make Waves
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: Smashing together, fusion, ripples, consequences.

title: Behind Your Eyes
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc:
When you close your eyes and sink into your real self.

Also, this is first of a new genre: vom-art.

EDIT: Ok nope, that idea is gone :(

title: Jalaxism
materials: Acrylic, sunflower oil, detergent on canvas
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc:
Although it's small this is one of the deepest of my semi-autonomous paintings.

If you're interested in how this painting was made there's an article about it here.

title: Flor De Noche Buena
desc:
The poinsettia is native to Mexico and Central America and is steeped in religious folklore. The title means flower of the good night and refers to Christmas Eve.

The Aztecs called it Cuetlaxochitle which roughly translates to shit-flower, possibly because birds ate the seeds and it grew from their droppings; good things can come from crap.

title: The Grass Sea Is Taller Than Me
desc: When I was little there was a patch at the end of the garden which got really overgrown and had some tall grass, I remember walking into it and having the grass towering above my head, being completely hidden. I've tried to recreate that feeling in this painting.

title: Building
desc: This looks like a pattern from a distance, but when you get close you look into the windows.

title: Splatstormm Blue
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: This thickly textured block of blue is made from acrylic modelling paste, gloss medium and uses iridescent medium to create metallic/pearlescent effects.

title: Splatstormm Red
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: This thickly textured block of red is made from acrylic modelling paste, gloss medium and uses iridescent medium to create metallic/pearlescent effects.

title: Splatstormm Green
desc: This thickly textured block of green is made from acrylic modelling paste, gloss medium and uses iridescent medium to create metallic/pearlescent effects.
commentPrompt: Are you angered by this unsightly blob?

title: Splatstormm Yellow
commentPrompt: Do you like abstract art or is it a waste of time?
desc: This thickly textured block of yellow is made from acrylic modelling paste, gloss medium and uses iridescent medium to create metallic/pearlescent effects.

title: Me in Smoke, Trying to Change Spots
commentPrompt: In what kind of places could this painting be hung?
desc:
Obviously not a literal self-portrait, this painting took more than a year to complete, spanning the time it took me to move out of London and resettle in Brighton.

It took me a long time to realise that I had been painting myself encaged in the city.

People often think this is a depressing painting but that was never the intention, to me it's just matter-of-fact.

title: Jagger
desc:
I loved that fish. I seem to remember that the gold acrylic I used was made from real gold, but that sounds ridiculous so I'm probably befuddled. The fish does glimmer as light moves across it anyway, unless I'm befuddling that too.

This got re-worked in 2012 when I removed the terrible old frame I had nailed to it years ago and found it to be discoloured underneath. I ended up repainting the background and much prefer the new version.

title: Thornton
desc: Thornton is a Lhasa Apso which is a Tibetan breed named after the capital city. Apso is the Tibetan word for 'bearded'.

title: Dalmation
desc: This commission came in response to a card advertising pet portraits I put in a post office window to earn extra cash while I was doing my art foundation course.

title: Cat
desc: This was painted while I was in school studying for my A-Levels, it has a style I've not managed to repeat since.

title: Monkey Mother and Child
desc: These are drawn/painted using brush-tipped pen on layout paper. The special wrinkled patina took 10 years of attic storage to achieve.

title: Chimps Learning
desc:
The chimps are learning how to use a rock to crack a nut by observation, a significant act in that it was previously thought (by some) that only humans were able to learn through pure observation in this way.

The source photo is not my own, it was copied from a nature book when I was 16 years old, learning to paint (that process is ongoing). The name of the book is lost so if anybody wants acknowledgement please let me know or just send some balaclava-wearing lawyers through my window, Iranian-embassy-seige style.

title: Freddie
desc:
My Grandad, I painted this for my nan. She was very moved because she really liked Johnny Cash and she thought it was him.

I should mention that she was even more pleased when I pointed out that it was actually Grandad.

title: Dan
desc:
This portrait was painted in the early nineties, which must be the only reason it always makes me think he's gonna step on you...you know you talk so hip man, you're twistin' my melon man.

Not in a great state but it's the only copy I have.

title: Jade & Damien
desc: My cousins.

title: Max
desc: The young Maximillian.

title: Sean & Foley
desc: Sean the famous man of Limerick and Bury St. Edmunds, with his mislaid dog, Foley. If you look at the reflection in the window you can see me sitting on the ground taking the photo and my friend standing beside me.

title: William Baillie
desc: William Ballie was in the Canadian Nova Scotia Regiment during WWII. Due to his heroic deeds in helping to release the village of Authie, in France, he has a school named after him, and his son Brian asked me to paint this portrait for them. The painting now hangs in the school.

title: Life Drawing
desc: I used to enjoy life drawing at college. The model was onto a good thing - she used to trundle along on her scooter, get her kit off and doze off reading her book. A couple of hours later we'd wake her up and she'd be back on the scooter again and off to another session. What a racket.

title: Self Portrait
desc:
Painting a self-portrait is difficult - analysing the way your own face looks! I think it is a good thing to do as a painter though, it documents your style and how it changes over time, and how the way you look changes over time too.

Check the date it was painted if you are thinking I look too skinny!

title: Ice Cube
desc: "If I'm more of an influence to your son as a rapper than you are as a father... you got to look at yourself as a parent."

title: Bob Dylan
desc: "A man is a success if he gets up in the morning and goes to bed at night, and inbetween he does what he wants to do."

title: Bob Marley
desc: "My music defends righteousness. If you're black and you're wrong, you're wrong; if you're white and you're wrong, you're wrong; if you're Indian and you're wrong, you're wrong. It's universal."

title: Flower 1
desc: This is one of three that I originally made, I lost track of one of them. Materials used include card, acrylic paint, dirt and P.V.A. glue.

title: Flower 2
desc: The second of the original three.

title: Shell
desc: I built this study of a seashell from corrugated card and acrylic paint. The spiral ridges are the exposed corrugations of varying thicknesses of box cardboard, with the outer skin peeled off.

title: Aztec Blue Eagle
desc:
A bird was needed for a local event, I was told it might be nice if it was a bit Aztec. Next thing I knew this fella was flapping around my flat.

This isn't a great photo, it's a bit blurry. The eagle has flown and disappeared so it's the best I have.

title: Albi the Alpaca
materials: Corrugated card, squash balls, cable ties, acrylic paint
desc: This alpaca (plus unnatural horns) was created for utility - to cover up an ugly central heating controller on a friend's wall.

title: Tlaloc
desc: This is my USB memory stick, I built it up with Miliput and carved this character into it, based on Tlaloc, the Aztec god of rain and fertility.

title: Crystalline City
desc: I had a college modelmaking brief to make an architectural model based on a natural structure - I chose a lead crystal (as viewed under an electron microscope).

title: Retro Lounge
desc: This tiny model was a project for my modelmaking college course.

title: Man and Woman
desc:
A tree formed from two intertwined figures, male and female. Don't feel bad if you can't see it, you aren't alone.

My favourite parts are the tiny transparent cubes. I found the spherical stone which stops the bottle in a field, I think it might be a musket ball.

title: Ladybird
desc: Modelled in paper mache and fur.

title: Adam in the garden, contemplating a spherical pear
materials: Beer mat, tennis ball, Apple RAM, bottle lids, sponges, clothes pegs, plastic jewels, glow-in-the-dark baby, shoelace, internals from an extension lead
desc: From the Four Seasons of Consciousness series of collages, this is Spring.
commentPrompt: 28 Elephant tickets?

title: Man on the beach, contemplating a ternary star system
materials: Fliers, earrings, elastic bands, plastic toys, canvas key wedges, wrapping paper, beads, clothing tag, Bury Free Press from 1991
desc: Summer in the Four Seasons of Consciousness series.

title: Dodecapede on the far side of Orion, contemplating the stargate
materials: colour swatches, earbud containers, plastic toys, insides of a jewellery box, fliers, cigarette tab, tinted glue gun glue, purple rubber, keyring tag, bouncy ball, bottle lids, beads
desc:
Four Seasons of Consciousness, Autumn

The constellation at the top-left is Orion but flipped horizontally, I presume that's how it would look if viewed from the other side.

title: The universe during the big crunch, contemplating itself in the form of man
materials: playing card, button, kids toy gun holster, staples, quartz crystal, beads, reflective material, polythene, polystyrene, zip pull, baking paper, notes from art classes back in the 90s
desc: Winter in the Four Seasons of Consciousness, the universe collapses in on itself in a big crunch event.

title: The Abbey Gate
desc: This was sort of for British Telecom. I painted it for a works raffle, when I worked for 192 Directory Enquiries just after leaving college.

title: The Abbey Gate
desc:
A commissioned revisit of Bury St. Edmunds' abbey gate painted twelve years previously

My favourite thing in this painting is the scene within a scene through the arch.

title: Party
desc:
This is an image straight from the mind of my friend Jane.

The 3D aeroplanes are made from Toffo wrappers - another curly-haired clown of a friend made them and threw them at me while I was painting, so on they got stuck.

title: Play Time
desc: I won't write too much about this one, I think it's more interesting to let the viewer make up his or her own story.

title: Interaction
desc: People bouncing off each other.

title: Sixty One Aliens
desc: I've intentionally left the faces without detail, it gives the characters a spooky quality and leaves the viewer to fill in the gaps.

title: Public Transport #10
commentPrompt: Are landscape paintings boring?
desc: Number 10 in a series of 12 views out of bus and train windows.

title: Public Transport #11
commentPrompt: Are landscape paintings boring?
desc: Number 11 in a series of 12 views out of bus and train windows.

title: Public Transport #12
commentPrompt: Are landscape paintings boring?
desc: Number 12 in a series of 12 views out of bus and train windows.

title: Yeastlings
desc: This is yeast proving.

title: Poppies
desc: An impressionistic field of poppies.

title: Pretty Yellow Flowers
desc: What can I say?

title: Star Dust
desc: Somehow tiny stars got scattered around my home. This is from inside the Hoover/Dyson.

title: Leech
desc: Look at how pretty and colourful it is.

title: Wrought Bench Reflections
desc: The reflections caught my eye, I couldn't resist.

title: Is That Me?
desc: Would a spider be looking at his reflection?

title: Spider #1
desc: Do you like it?

title: Gull #1
desc: It's a seagull.

title: Mustard
desc: There's a lot of colour to be found here in something that at first glance can look quite bland.

title: Measured Progress
desc: About a hundred of these caterpillars lived in and around my flat for a while.

title: Burn Up and Across
desc: It's all there.

title: Capillaries
desc: Just, draining.

title: Begets
desc: Start as you mean to go on.

title: Wastage
desc: Blotted.

title: Designed Litter
desc: Looks good on the floor.

title: Japanese Trees and Stars
desc: But they're not.

title: Ewe In't From Round Ear Are Ewe Baa?
desc: I got out alive.

title: Enclosed
desc: A place of happenings.

title: Industrial Processes
desc: Shiz happenz.

title: Cabbage Knows All
desc: Fractals.

title: Do Not Ignore Me
desc: Under the bridge.

title: Night Not Swimming
desc: Long exposure on an eerie night.

title: Got to Get In
desc: Coming up.

title: Baked Ice
desc: I finally found out how water is made.

title: Frozen Candle
desc: A scientific experiment to find out if it was possible to freeze a flame. Yes it did work, totally.

title: Morning in Gold
desc: Sin shining through net curtains. I love that typo, it's staying.

title: Trolley Train
desc: I like the infinite grid effect.

title: Bench Warrior
desc: I was walking one morning when I suddenly found myself surrounded by several of these beings.

title: Strangling Self in the Rain
desc:
A see-through plastic drawer on its side. Contents: printer stuff, visible at the front are some lint-free towels splotched with pigment ink.

The dark spots for eyes and red mouth were easily enough to let my brain see a face.

title: Whiteboard Glue
desc: I like to take things apart and keep the bits to prevent my flat from becoming too tidy. Peeling the thin metal sheet away from the wood of an old whiteboard revealed this filigree splendour.

title: Paper Motion
desc: Can you feel it? Can you feel it? Can you feel it?
commentPrompt: If you rearrange all of the letters in this photo you can spell the name of a famous Ukranian actress. Who is she?

title: Painted Leaf
desc: This is a photograph but people often assume it's a painting.

title: Leaf Carpet
desc: These are the natural colours of the leaves. I'll be painting this soon as I love this photo.

title: Laterite Mountain
desc: The earth around Goa is laterite soil, which is red due to its containing iron oxide. The man standing on top of this mound of mined material was handy as he gave my photo scale.

title: Tiny Beach People
desc:
I know this is a weird one, there's something I like about it though.

The people aren't really tiny, they're far away - just like in Father Ted (or the story I read years ago about a previously-undiscovered tribe who had under-developed depth perception due to their living in thick forest; upon being discovered and taken outside their homeland to an open hillside they remarked on the tiny goats on the neighbouring hill; allegedly).

See the man with the flat cap?

title: London Buses
desc: Caught this not long after the 7/7 London bombings, all the buses lined up outside the MI6 building

title: Deep Sea Lurkins
desc: Salty green gerkins.

title: Alien Fruit
desc: I'd love to know what it eventually hatched into.

title: Flaming Bejewelled
desc: It's over-saturated, covered in lens-flare and totally garish, but it loves me.

title: Puppet Fish
desc: "I find his face amusing". Yeah I hear that a lot.

title: Eye of the Panther
desc: Oh actually it's the froth on a cup of coffee.

title: Ancient Electronics
desc: I saw this over the door of a train, I like the old-style electronics with visible components, so much more interesting than silicon chips.

title: Sunset in Hair-tent, Longneck Flies Overhead
desc: Yeah that's right, that's what I'm calling it.

title: Agoraphobia
desc: The outside world looks scary.

title: Purgatory
desc: Stuck outside the gates of hell. Annoying.

title: Sun #2
desc: A hot drink of Swiss Bouillon.

title: Sun #3
desc: A liquidiser half-full of liquidised persimmon (Sharon fruit) was placed on top of a lamp and a camera was aimed down into it. This made far more sense than eating the flavourless buggers.

title: Moon #1
desc: This is the view looking down into an emptied cup of tea. The image was then inverted (like colour-reversal film or a negative effect) in Photoshop and the overall brightness levels were tweaked.

title: Moon #2
desc:
A hazy moon drifts over a sparsely-scrubbed hillside.

Well actually this is my sparsely-scrubbed chinny-chin-chin, colour-inverted in Photoshop. The moon is a smoke-detector on the ceiling, and the whole image is flipped vertically.

title: Heat Tint
desc: These excellent colours appeared on the bottom of a stainless steel pan, apparently it may have been caused by overheating.

title: Pixel Cloth
desc:
This patterned cloth, backlit by the sun reminds me of fire. If you use the magnifier to zoom in you'll see how the design is pixelated.

I associate pixels with computers but the loom brought them into the world a long time before that and is linked to early computers in other ways too.

title: Intersection
desc:
This is a hypothetical intersection between a black hole and a white hole.

It's a greasy pan spattered with flour.

title: And Ganesh Came Down
desc:
I'm not sure if Ganesh would object to being depicted in this Las Vegas manner but the taxi driver whose cab this effigy was in didn't seem to think he would.

Overblown LEDs are entirely intentional on my part, I like the pink corona it creates.

title: Bulbous Squinteye
desc: Where some might see only a washing-up liquid bottle I see a hollow, transparent alien being, one eye bigger than the other, half filled with green life-giving fluid. So?
